bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.S. Galbreath, August 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench comments on the Kissingers. He appreciates the medical care Galbreath is providing them.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.S. Galbreath, August 20, 1941
div1.opener:
August 20, 1941
Dr. R. S. Galbreath
16 West Washington Street
Huntington, Indiana
My dear Doctor Galbreath:
div1.p:
I do appreciate greatly your letter telling me the low down on
the medical manners of the Kissingers. I must admit I am not surprised.
They are nice, simple people but I do think that by virtue of illness and
for other reasons they have both lost their independence and are a bit
willing to rely on the world for their sustenance.

I am glad to know that Mr. Kissinger is better and able to be up
and around. I visited him a few years ago and promised to do so again.
Perhaps I can stop off on my way East sometime this Fall.

I am sure that if he gets in any serious medical trouble he
could be admitted to a government hospital without any trouble. Perhaps
the Veterans Hospital at Indianapolis would admit him. In the meantime,
as a colleague, I appreciate what you are doing for them, and hope that
you, like most of us physicians, will get your reward by means of self
satisfaction and perhaps in some future sphere.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
